title.narrative: Reliable water supply for communities in Cebu

description.narrative: The negative impacts on the health and quality of life of people who do not have access to safe water and basic sanitation are huge. Especially for poor and vulnerable people who live and work in the most overcrowded and polluted areas of the cities. Cebu is one of these cities where the poor are vulnerable to an unhygienic and unreliable water supply. This area also has its fair share of annual disasters, including earthquakes and typhoons. These cause serious damage to any existing water supply, with the poorest people having to carry the heaviest burden.

The project consists of three different courses of action. First there is an improved access to clean drinking water supply, this water supplier (MCWD) will also become more sustainable as a result of the increased customer base. Additional health gains are achieved through community programs that increase the resilience of very poor communities. Finally the resilience of the community against disasters is also improved through the provision of backup power for the MCWD's critical production sites.
The project takes place in the Philippines' second largest urban centre, Metro Cebu.

The project will provide huge benefits to the poor, bringing safe water supply to 80,000. 30.000 of these belong to the poorest people in the slums of Cebu. These people are also the targets for the community programs to enhance health gains. The leading implementing partner Metro Cebu Water District working in cooperation with Vitens Evides International and with support from The Red Cross.
This project provides huge benefits to the poor through improving the access to clean drinking water and sanitation.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

title.narrative: WASH - Sanitation
Latrine and hand washing facility construction according to national standards in 12 number of schools, health facilities and markets.
# men, women and children have access to safe sanitary facilities.
Increased capability of communities to respond and recover from disasters / public health threats.
Men, women and children in the target population have increased access to water and sanitation facilities and are able take action to protect themselves against threats to public health.
Private sector is able to provide sanitation services and products for the right price at the right place
Strengthened partnerships to establish an enabling environment and sustainability of the WatSan, health and disaster management initiatives.
WatSan Committees are formed and functioning; lead planning and implementation of community-based activities
WASH - Hygiene promotion
# men, women and children are enabled to practice safer hygiene in a dignified and culturally appropriate manner
Community adhere to new hygiene behaviours and practices
Community health volunteers facilitate provision of basic health and hygiene promotion services
Other - Project Sustainability
An improved sustainability of the MCWD, with an improved pro-poor focus and with better technical skills.
Sustainability Pact has been developed and signed by local partners responsible for continuation of the activities after the project
WASH - Water
Contracts signed with 10,000 households in the areas for new water supply connections
Connections implemented to at least 80% of households with whom contracts were signed by the end of the project period.
A completed plan showing how backup power supply to 27 water production facilities can improve resilience against natural disasters
Allocated budget verified for the backup power generation to the earmarked water production facilities
Communities, local authorities and the Red Cross have increased capacity to respond to emergencies
Completed Water Safety Plan
Completed campaign to sign up new customers in poor areas to which new distribution and stub-outs were installed
Contracts prepared with each target household for water supply connections
Cooperation obtained from municipal authorities for water supply into depressed areas (slum areas)
Distribution and stub-outs completed into depressed areas to allow construction of water supply connections
Improved access to clean drinking water for 30,000 people in depressed areas
Improved communication between consumers and water service providers more appropriate services and increased willingness to pay
In total 5,000 water supply connections completed for poor families in slum areas, with connections constructed with the help of labour from the target areas
Labour employed from the target areas for the construction of connections in depressed areas
Local staff, at least 70% female, found employment in running the operations, also after the project
Much less money and time spent by households affected on supply of water
Team(s) established, with at least 70% female participation, to interview target households if they will participate in water supply scheme
Other - People reached
Improved access to clean drinking water for 10,000 households (50,000 people) of which 8,000 during the project period
Improved well-being and health for all households affected
Poverty alleviation: Sustained economic improvement for the households affected
Strongly improved well-being and health for all households affected by the project
People who received direct services that contribute to their resilience
Livelihoods
Improved operations of production and distribution facilities through on the job and classroom trained staff
Intensive on the job and classroom trained staff in technical and financial project management
Sustained economic improvement for the households affected.
